revision.text:
[[File:Tò he.JPG|thumb|Tò he]] [[File:Making a "tò he".JPG|thumb|A tò he craftsman at work]] [[File:To he.JPG|thumb|right|250px|A tò he craftsman with children.]] '''Tò he''' (''toy figurine'') is a traditional toy for children in [[Vietnam]] which is made from glutinous [[rice powder]] in form of edible figurine such as animals, flowers or characters in folk stories.<ref>[http://www.vanishingsaigon.com/2010/05 /to-he/ ]</ref> In the past, ''tò he'' was made and sold only on the occasion of festivals, especially the [[Tết]] and the [[Mid-Autumn Festival|Trung Thu]] which are the favorite festivals of Vietnamese children. Nowadays, the toy is introduced in almost all traditional festivals and in public places like parks or gardens. As tò he is one of the rare surviving traditional toys of Vietnam, the art of tò he making is considered a cultural ambassador of Vietnam and there are many efforts in order to preserve and develop this traditional art.
==Making== To create a ''tò he'' figurine, the craftsman needs a mixture of glutinous and ordinary [[rice powder]]s which is easily to knead into different shapes and edible for children, [[bamboo]] sticks to plant the shaped tò he and his own skill in graphic depicting.<ref name=Lecourrier>{{cite web |url=http://lecourrier.vnagency.com.vn/default.asp?xt=xt33&page=newsdetail&newsid=53359 |title= Millénaire de Thang Long : la vitalité des tò he de Xuân La |date=2009-06-17 |publisher=''Le Courrier du Vietnam |language=French |author=My Anh}}</ref> Modeled by the hand of the craftsmen, the forms of tò he figurine are drawn from animals, flowers and characters in folk stories such as [[Sun Wukong|Tôn Ngộ Không]], the Monkey King in ''[[Journey to the West]]''. There are seven basic colours of tò he figurines which are green, sea blue, red, purple, yellow, white and black, those colours come from rice powder mixed with [[food dye]]s which are used to replace colours from trees or ashes in order to ensure the edibleness of tò he.<ref name=Vietnamnet0902>{{cite web |url=http://english.vietnamnet.vn/features/2008/09/801689/ |title=The vitality of To he craft village |date=2008-09-02 |publisher=Vietnamnet.vn |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090219120300/http://english.vietnamnet.vn/features/2008/09/801689/ |archivedate=2009-02-19 |df= }}</ref> In the past, tò he was steamed after being kneaded but today the figurines are made directly from preboiled paste so that the craftsman can reduce the time for making one tò he figurine.<ref name=Kendall>{{cite book |title=Vietnam: journeys of body, mind, and spirit |pages=98–99 |author=Nguyễn Văn Huy, Laurel Kendall |publisher=University of California Press |year=2003 |isbn=0-520-23872-9}}</ref> The paste is made from glutinous and ordinary rice powders, it was kneaded with fresh water before dropped in boiling water for one hour and finally dyed with food colour.<ref name=ttvh>{{cite web |url=http://www.thethaovanhoa.vn/285N20080827083648822T0/to-hevan-vung-vang-mot-suc-song.htm |title=Tò he - vẫn vững vàng một sức sống |date=2008-08-27 |publisher=Thethaovanhoa.vn |author=Trung Kiên |language=Vietnamese}}</ref>
The procedure of tò he making requires utmost patience from the craftsman, but almost all tò he makers are men and there is an unwritten law in families of tò he craftsmen that secret in making tò he is only passed from father to sons and daughters-in-law, not to daughters. There are no lesson of tò he making, sons are transmitted the skill from their father solely in watching and self-learning.<ref name=Vietnamnet0902/><ref name=Vietnamnet0705>{{cite web |url=http://english.vietnamnet.vn/lifestyle/2005/05/422527/ |title=Rare children’s art goes to US, puts Xuan La on map |date=2005-05-07 |publisher=Vietnamnet.vn |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090430125310/http://english.vietnamnet.vn/lifestyle/2005/05/422527/ |archivedate=2009-04-30 |df= }}</ref> Nevertheless, nowadays tò he making is also taught to the handicapped so that they can live on making tò he and other forms of traditional art.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://english.vietnamnet.vn/features/2008/08/800051/ |title=Centre hands disabled a better future |publisher=Vietnamnet.vn |date=2008-08-22 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090223002010/http://english.vietnamnet.vn/features/2008/08/800051/ |archivedate=2009-02-23 |df= }}</ref>
==History== [[File:To he Vietnam.jpg|thumb|left|250px|A tò he craftsman making an animal figurine besides the [[Temple of Literature, Hanoi]].]] Traditionally, tò he craftsmen had a compact set of tools so that in one day they could go to several common places such as [[Market (place)|markets]], [[Vietnamese communal temple|communal temple ground]]s and especially local festivals where children often gathered to play or accompany their parents. According to the old generation of tò he craftsmen, the origin of tò he making was dated to the 17th century.<ref name=Vietnamnet0902/> The two most important occasions each year for tò he craftsmen are [[Tết]] and [[Mid-Autumn Festival|Trung Thu]] because they are the favorite festivals for Vietnamnese children.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://english.vietnamnet.vn/lifestyle/2008/09/803515/ |title=The Traditional Mid Autumn Festival |date=2008-09-13 |publisher=Vietnamnet.vn |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090103093658/http://english.vietnamnet.vn/lifestyle/2008/09/803515/ |archivedate=2009-01-03 |df= }}</ref>
Nowadays, tò he is made and sold not only during the [[Tết]] holiday and other festivals but also all year round in public place like [[park]]s, [[garden]]s.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://english.vietnamnet.vn/lifestyle/2009/01/822125/ |title=Hanoi to have lantern festival for Tet |publisher=Vietnamnet.vn |date=2009-01-05 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20091005020456/http://english.vietnamnet.vn/lifestyle/2009/01/822125/ |archivedate=2009-10-05 |df= }}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://english.vietnamnet.vn/lifestyle/2009/02/826677/ |title=Buying luck at Vieng Market |publisher=Vietnamnet.vn |date=2009-02-02 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090501145745/http://english.vietnamnet.vn/lifestyle/2009/02/826677/ |archivedate=2009-05-01 |df= }}</ref> The price for a figurine sold in [[Hanoi]] varies from 3,000 to 5,000 [[VND]].<ref name=Vietnamnet0902/><ref name=ttvh/> There is a village in the countryside of Hanoi where many people earn their living by making and selling tò he, it is Xuân La village which has about 200 tò he craftsmen and almost all villagers from children to adults can make tò he figurine in a very brief period.<ref name=Lecourrier/> Facing the threat from modern toys and other forms of entertainment,<ref>{{cite web |url=http://vietnamnews.vnagency.com.vn/showarticle.php?num=01SUN041009 |title=Festivals may be toymakers’ swansong |date=2009-10-04 |publisher=[[Vietnam News Agency]]}}</ref> tò he craftsmen have to be more and more creative so that their figurines can appear more lively and closer to the children,<ref name=Vietnamnet0902/> for that reason tò he figurines today can be also modeled after characters from international films and cartoons such as [[Doraemon]], [[Pikachu]] and even [[Sailor Moon (character)|Sailor Moon]] with her very own blond hair.<ref name=Kendall/>
As one of the rare surviving traditional toys in modern time, tò he is considered a cultural ambassador of Vietnam. Some craftsmen are invited to the [[United States]] or [[South Korea]] to perform the art of tò he making.<ref name=Lecourrier/><ref name=Vietnamnet0705/> Another positive sign for the existence of tò he is that the Ministry of Culture and Information of Vietnam has paid more attention in preserving and propagating this traditional art.<ref name=Vietnamnet0902/> A tò he craftsman from [[Thái Bình]] was presented with medal from the Vietnam Folk Literature and Art Association for his effort in preserving the art of tò he making<ref>{{cite web |url=http://english.vietnamnet.vn/lifestyle/2008/12/821078/ |title=Vietnam Folk Literature and Art Awards 2008 presented |date=2008-12-29 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090104071132/http://english.vietnamnet.vn/lifestyle/2008/12/821078/ |archivedate=2009-01-04 |df= }}</ref> while tò he is frequently introduced in cultural festivals.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://english.vietnamnet.vn/lifestyle/2004/11/347011/ |title=Further details for the Vietnam-Japan Festival |date=2004-11-18 |publisher=Vietnamnet.vn |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20071010013414/http://english.vietnamnet.vn/lifestyle/2004/11/347011/ |archivedate=2007-10-10 |df= }}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://english.vietnamnet.vn/lifestyle/2005/02/376993/ |title=Vietnam to open the first national Ca Tru Festival |date=2005-02-17 |publisher=Vietnamnet.vn |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080527083213/http://english.vietnamnet.vn/lifestyle/2005/02/376993/ |archivedate=2008-05-27 |df= }}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://english.vietnamnet.vn/lifestyle/200912/HCM-City-welcomes-the-New-Year-with-festivals-886635/ |title=HCM City welcomes the New Year with festivals |date=2009-12-18 |publisher=Vietnamnet.vn |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100117020942/http://english.vietnamnet.vn/lifestyle/200912/HCM-City-welcomes-the-New-Year-with-festivals-886635/ |archivedate=2010-01-17 |df= }}</ref> Tò he is brought to the poor children of the mountainous region in the North of Vietnam who cannot afford to buy toys, they are also given instructions to make simple forms of tò he figurines.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://english.vietnamnet.vn/social/2008/05/785786/ |title=Poor children in Hoa Binh get toys |date=2008-05-30 |publisher=Vietnamnet.vn |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090503063020/http://english.vietnamnet.vn/social/2008/05/785786/ |archivedate=2009-05-03 |df= }}</ref>
==See also== * [[Amezaiku]] * [[Sugar people]]
== References == {{Reflist|2}}

revision.comment: Rescuing 6 sources and tagging 0 as dead. #IABot (v2.0beta2)
revision.text:
'''Uznews.net''' was an independent Uzbek news website that operated from 2005 to 2014. As of 2010, it had been blocked by the Uzbek government for several years.{{cite web |url=http://www.forum18.org/Archive.php?article_id=1422 |title=Uzbekistan: Internet censorship continues |author=Felix Corley and Mushfig Bayram |date=16 March 2010 |publisher=Forum 18 |accessdate=10 June 2011}} The website's editor-in-chief is [[Galima Bukharbaeva]], an Uzbek journalist known for her eyewitness coverage of the 2005 [[Andijan massacre]];{{cite web |url=http://www.uznews.net/news_single.php?lng=en&sub=usual&cid=3&nid=17297 |title=Uzbek embassy tells police to stop campaign for release of journalists |date=11 May 2011 |work= |publisher=uznews.net |accessdate=10 June 2011}} she later won the [[CPJ International Press Freedom Awards|International Press Freedom Award]] of the [[Committee to Protect Journalists]].{{cite web |url=http://cpj.org/awards/2005/galima.php |title=IPFA 2005 - Galima Bukharbaeva |author= |year=2005 |work= |publisher=Committee to Protect Journalists |accessdate=10 June 2011}} Uznews.net reporter [[Salijon Abdurahmanov]] was arrested during a traffic stop on 7 June 2008, who searched his car and stated that they found {{convert|114|g|oz}} of marijuana and {{convert|5|g|oz}} of opium in his trunk.{{cite web |url=http://www.rferl.org/content/uzbekistan-presents-impostor-to-red-cross/24776137.html |title=Uzbek Prison Shows 'Impostor' To Red Cross |date=20 November 2012 |publisher=Radio Free Europe |accessdate=23 November 2012 |archivedate=24 November 2012 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6CPCavns4?url=http://www.rferl.org/content/uzbekistan-presents-impostor-to-red-cross/24776137.html |deadurl=no |df=dmy-all }}{{cite web |url=http://cpj.org/2008/10/uzbek-journalist-slammed-with-10-year-prison-term.php |title=Uzbek slammed with 10-year prison term |date=10 October 2008 |publisher=Committee to Protect Journalists |accessdate=23 November 2012 |archivedate=24 November 2012 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6CPFNX9jB?url=http://cpj.org/2008/10/uzbek-journalist-slammed-with-10-year-prison-term.php |deadurl=no |df=dmy-all }} Abdurahmanov stated that the drugs had been planted in retaliation for an uznews.net story he had recently published about alleged corruption of traffic police. He was found guilty and sentenced to ten years in prison in October 2008. The conviction drew protests from a number of international human rights organizations, including [[Amnesty International]] (which named him a [[prisoner of conscience]]),{{cite web |url=http://www.rferl.org/content/Amnesty_Declares_Uzbek_Journalist_Prisoner_Of_Conscience/1189028.html |title=Amnesty Declares Uzbek Journalist Prisoner Of Conscience |date=6 August 2008 |publisher=Radio Free Europe |accessdate=23 November 2012 |archivedate=24 November 2012 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6CPDcy7ZJ?url=http://www.rferl.org/content/Amnesty_Declares_Uzbek_Journalist_Prisoner_Of_Conscience/1189028.html |deadurl=no |df=dmy-all }} [[Human Rights Watch]],{{cite web |url=http://www.highbeam.com/doc/1P3-1575866131.html |title=Uzbekistan: Journalist Sentenced to 10 Years |date=11 October 2008 |publisher=US Federal News Service {{Subscription required|via=[[HighBeam Research]]}}|accessdate=24 November 2012}} the Committee to Protect Journalists,{{cite web |url=http://cpj.org/blog/2012/05/cpj-calls-for-release-of-jailed-reporters-in-centr.php#more |title=CPJ calls for release of jailed reporters in Central Asia |date=15 May 2012 |publisher=Committee to Protect Journalists |accessdate=23 November 2012 |archivedate=24 November 2012 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6CPDXnfGA?url=http://cpj.org/blog/2012/05/cpj-calls-for-release-of-jailed-reporters-in-centr.php#more |deadurl=no |df=dmy-all }} the [[International Federation for Human Rights]],{{cite web |url=http://www.fidh.org/CONFIRMATION-IN-APPEAL-OF-MR |title=Confirmation in Appeal of Mr. Salijon Abdurahmanov's Sentence to Ten Years in Prison |date=11 December 2008 |publisher=International Federation for Human Rights |accessdate=23 November 2012 |archivedate=24 November 2012 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6CPDO9yZM?url=http://www.fidh.org/CONFIRMATION-IN-APPEAL-OF-MR |deadurl=no |df=dmy-all }} and the [[Organization for Security and Co-operation in Europe]].{{cite web |url=http://www.rferl.org/content/OSCE_Says_Uzbekistan_Made_Up_Charges_Against_Journalist/1330368.html |title=OSCE Says Uzbekistan Made Up Charges Against Journalist |date=16 October 2008 |publisher=Radio Free Europe |accessdate=23 November 2012 |archivedate=24 November 2012 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6CPFv7U1j?url=http://www.rferl.org/content/OSCE_Says_Uzbekistan_Made_Up_Charges_Against_Journalist/1330368.html |deadurl=no |df=dmy-all }} As of December 20, 2014, the news site is shut down and all links redirect to the following message in Uzbek, Russian, and English:
Uznews.net has ceased to exist. We thank all our readers for having been with us and a separate thank you to the most faithful who are logging in now. We are touched. Uznews.net Team (January 2005 - December 2014)
A tribute article by Reporters Without Borders stated that the email of editor-in-chief Galima Bukharbayeva was hacked and confidential information identifying independent journalists who contributed to UzNews.net was leaked to the public.http://en.rsf.org/ouzbekistan-tribute-to-leading-news-site-that-14-01-2015,47482.html While all of the content has been taken down from the site, it is still accessible from the [[Internet Archive]]. == References == {{Reflist|33em}} == External links == *{{official website|http://www.uznews.net/}} [[Category:Media in Uzbekistan]] {{uzbekistan-media-stub}}

revision.text:
{{refimprove|date=September 2014}} {{Use dmy dates|date=November 2010}} The '''Warsaw Theatre Directorate''' (''Warszawskie Teatry Rządowe'') was the chief authority for theatres in the [[Duchy of Warsaw]] in [[Warsaw]] during the 19th and early 20th centuries. It was set up by decree of [[Frederick Augustus I of Saxony]] on 14 April 1810 as the ''Rządowa Dyrekcja Teatru'' (Government Directorate for Theatre), its draft statute having been developed by [[Wojciech Bogusławski|Wojciecha Bogusławskiego]]. In 1822 it changed its name to ''Dyrekcja Teatrów i Wszelkich Widowisk Dramatycznych i Muzycznych w Królestwie'' (Directorate of all theatres and dramatic and musical performance in the Kingdom), then in 1833 to the Warsaw Theatre Directorate. It ceased to exist in July 1915.
It guided theatrical output and provided theatres with financial stability, enabling shows in Polish to be put on and new theatre buildings to be constructed. Its companies included ones for operettas, ballets, dramas, comedies, the [[National Theatre, Warsaw|National Theatre]] and later opera and farce. It had 5 buildings: * from 1833 - [[Great Theatre, Warsaw|Teatr Wielki]] and the [[Teatr Rozmaitości, Warsaw|Teatr Rozmaitości]] * from 1870 - [[Teatr Letni, Warsaw|Teatr Letni]] * from 1880 - [[Teatr Mały, Warsaw (1880-1901)|Teatr Mały]] * from 1881 - [[Teatr Nowy, Warsaw (1881-1901)|Teatr Nowy]] * from 1901 - [[Teatr Nowości]]
== Presidents == The body's president was supported by a board of governors and by directors, and from 1907 by literary managers. {| class="wikitable" |- !From !|To !President |- || 1810 || 1813 || [[Julian Ursyn Niemcewicz]] |- || 1814 || 1820 || [[Józef Lipiński (teacher)|Józef Lipiński]] |- || 1821 || 1830 || [[Aleksander Rożniecki]] |- || 1832 || 1842 || [[Józef Rautenstrauch]] |- || 1842 || 1862 || [[Ignacy Abramowicz]] |- || 1862 || 1868 || [[A. Hauke]] |- || 1868 || 1880 || [[Siergiej Muchanow]] |- || 1880 || 1882 || [[Wsiewołod Wsiewołożski]] |- || 1882 || 1889 || [[Longin Gudowski]] |- || 1889 || 1892 || [[Dymitr Palicyn]] |- || 1892 || 1895 || [[Aleksander Karandiejew]] |- || 1895 || 1897 || [[Piotr Andriejew]] |- || 1898 || 1901 || [[Paweł Iwanow]] |- || 1901 || 1908 || [[Konstantin Herschelman]] |- || 1908 || 1914 || [[Jurij Małyszew (director)|Jurij Małyszew]] |- || 1914 || 1915 || [[Jurij Burman]] |}
==Sources== *Bartłomiej tytuł= Encyklopedia Warszawy Kaczorowski: Warszawa: Wydaw. Naukowe PWN, 1994, s. 933, 934. {{ISBN|83-01-08836-2}}. *Maria Olga Bieńka: Warszawskie teatry rządowe : dramat i komedia : 1890-1915. Warszawa: Instytut Sztuki Polskiej Akademii Nauk, 2003. {{ISBN|83-89101-12-2}}. *''Teatr polski w latach 1890-1918.'' Warszawa: PWN, 1988, s. 272. {{ISBN|978-83-01-06777-9}}.
